title: Property of Linear Functions
text: Linear functions preserve vector addition. For example, $$f{\left(x+y\right)}=f{\left(x\right)}+f{\left(y\right)}$$.

title: Property of Linear Functions
text: Linear functions also must preserve scalar multiplication. For example, $$f(cx)=cf(x)$$ for a constant value c.

title: Linear Combinations
text: The name for the function that preserves both vector addition and scalar multiplication is a function that preserves linear combinations.

title: Simple Checking
text: The easiest vectors to input into the function to check that linear combinations are preserved are the elementary basis vectors e_1,...,e_n

title: Meaning of $$n$$
text: The $$n$$ denotes the dimension of the input vector, or more specifically that $$x$$ has two components.

title: $$x$$ values in f(x)
text: Since the function only has a $$x_1$$ value, the $$x_2$$ component of the function does not matter.

title: Checking for Linear Combinations
text: Is the outcome equal for f(\mat{(1),(0)}+\mat{(1),(0)}) and f(\mat{(1),(0)})+f(\mat{(1),(0)})?
